doc.abstracts: Cote d’Ivoire has continued its momentum in 2015. Growth maintained around 9 percent supported by investments both public and private, with the rapid developments in construction, transport, and finances sectors, since 2014, the performance of agriculture has notably improved. Monetary policy continues to be obviously anchored on regional policy, with a growth in money supply slightly higher than that of the economy. Other good news includes the acceleration of private sector credit while those towards the central government decreased. The international environment has also been favorable to Cote d’Ivoire with the persistence of higher prices for its main exports, the recovery in the European Union - the country’s main trading partner, and the depreciation of the Franc Communauté Financière Africaine (FCFA) against the United States (U.S.) 10 dollars. The outlook of the Ivoirian economy remains positives with growth that is expected around 8.5 percent over the next two years. Such growth will continue to be fueled by public investments, notably through public-private partnerships. Particular attention is needed for the budgetary risks coming from the financial losses of state-owned enterprises (SOEs) such as the Ivoirian Refining Company (SIR), Petroci and several public banks.
